body:
In my opinion, all these problems with $ref (#1258, #1259, #1260) are linked to a fundamental defect in the resolution of references, namely, the design choice to "flatten" things (probably for easier caching).

Ok I got it, if I flatten everything with no $ref, I 'll get it allright...
But this would defeat the purpose of SWAGGER spec '$ref' feature, that is allowing for heavy reuse of the underlying data model as message definitions for the interface.

there are 2 different use cases here.

1. editing specs and sharing pre-existing schemas by using references and promoting reuse
2. generating code where on an API boundary what goes over the wire has no concept of reuse or types just shapes of data.

So whether we flatten prior to the generation process or during the generation process by resolving refs ad-hoc should be of no consequence. The shape of the data is the same. The generation process works as follows:

1. resolve remote references and make them local
2. move all anonymous schemas into definitions and give them a name
3. generate an intermediate DOM (AST) from the specification that can be used for code generation
4. Pass AST to a number of templates and render code based on the information within the AST.

Thank you Ivan for your reply. Agree with your definitions of the use cases.
Agree too that flattening should, theoretically, make no difference (unless we get type naming conflicts in the definition tree, which might occur, but let's put that aside...).

My opinion above was supported by my investigations of the various $ref issues found yesterday, in particular the way the modifiyRef() works. I may have misinterpreted its inner workings, as I am not (yet) familiar with the code base.
In the reported case ('xxx has no key', #1258), the generator desperately tries to find the key at the root of definitions whereas it has been already been defined deeper by the $ref. I inferred (perhaps mistakenly) that the flattening was the problem.

issue.title: Server generation: open 'xxx.json/yyy.json' no such file or directory [cascading $ref]
issue.body:
## Problem statement
Server generation fails when referring to cascading $ref in different schema files.
Reference base path is wrongly formed.
```
>swagger generate server -f ../../models/test2-swagger.yaml 
The swagger spec at "../../models/test2-swagger.yaml" is invalid against swagger specification 2.0. see errors :
- open ./test2-schema.json/test2-bis-schema.json: no such file or directory
```

## Swagger specification
2.0
## Steps to reproduce
Swagger YAML files: ($ref to JSON file 1)
[test2-swagger.yaml.txt](https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/files/1481551/test2-swagger.yaml.txt)


JSON schema file #1: ($ref to JSON file 2)
[test2-schema.json.txt](https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/files/1481556/test2-schema.json.txt)


JSON schema file #2 
[test2-bis-schema.json.txt](https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger/files/1481557/test2-bis-schema.json.txt)


## Environment
swagger version: build from source cloned from origin/master
```
>git describe
0.12.0-49-g783e5bb
>
```
go version: 1.9
OS:   linux ubuntu 14.04

issue.title: Ref resolution changes in the swagger binary side
issue.body:
fixes #1258 (after the spec fix)
fixes #1259 
fixes #1270 
fixes #1065 
fixes #1034

body: The problem is with the id field which openapi 2.0 doesn't support.

@casualjim I have to disagree with your explanation:
- I tested with and without id or $id in the JSON schema part: same behaviour
- id or $id JSON schema keywords are not explicitly unsupported in OpenAPI 2.0, this precision comes from 3.0
[as per https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/master/versions/2.0.md, I could not find an equivalent to 3.0's: https://swagger.io/docs/specification/data-models/keywords)

However, it is interesting to get this view and move it to the spec validator. In this case, we should choose wether to ignore "id" or "$id" (I don't think it is used for $ref resolution anyhow) or to have the `spec validate` to shoot a validation error on this. 

I'll work next week on the spec validation part, as I found out I spent too much time cleaning my (long) specs figuring out errors.

see here: https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/master/versions/2.0.md#schemaObject

the supported properties are the ones defined in that list

Todo on that one:
- [ ] Test the effect of #1285 on the reported test cases
- [ ] Test the impact of id and $id in this context
- [ ] Move id, $id dectection to spec validation layer, with error or warning (to be decided, depending on impact)

Thanks Karim. this is exactly what I observed (and hopefully, reported).
So do we all agree that Id /$Id is something that should probably be a warning in spec validate (I can take cae of that)?

The problem specifically here is that the analyzer does not recognize that "B" is a "complex type" that should not be zeroed with make().

This has something to do with the $ref (inline schema works) but should be narrowed to the array case (object works). I may try to narrow it further, as a I only tested the Response case. I didn't check the behaviour for param in this case.

For $id, I will let @casualjim answer that but in general, $id is almost already supported https://github.com/go-openapi/spec/blob/master/expander.go#L629

The only case where $id is not supported is when a $ref is pointing to a subschema that doesn't have an $id but inherits its $id from a parent schema/subschema.

To support this case, any $ref should not only get resolved but the whole file pointed to by the $ref should get analyzed to identify the $id of the particular subschema the $ref is pointing to.
I remove the relationship to "$ref": the problem lies with the correct identification of a composed structure by the generator. I believe that forcing the Zero when composing struct should work.

Situation is much better with spec updated to master: thanks to the response expansion, OAIxxx types are now gone.
There is still a little glitch with the response template which omits proper pointer assignment then that should be ok. Plan to fix that soon.
